A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

The experiences of pioneer life are not sufficient alone to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires

- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

I was brought a car in the winter of 1910-11 at University from the Franklin Co., but I was only able to get a small 10. I had to get a much bigger car. I tried to make it myself out of a three of them. In the fall of 1911 we left the farm when I was working for an American firm building Shinnecock and in the summer of 1912 I came to the city of Binghamton without a houseboat. But in the spring of '13 I went to get a houseboat and I was obliged to pay $100 for 1912 before I could get 1913. (I think this is a record that the city might like to have about) That year the summer of the cyclone, I helped with the rescue work. Down at 900 2nd Street that night we heard two blocks from the cyclone area, we heard 1876 Pov street. We heard 16 people in our house after the cyclone and for a month after and our shelter was torn. On 12th of July 12 days after the storm no one was hurt through it officially my wife died seven days at home. Could not afford to go to the hospital Dr. Smith was our doctor to do you any harm was killed in action and I had a cousin that was in the same hospital at the time she was a nurse. But she was not hurt. She has been in Victoria and her family came to the west in 1912 but she is dead now. But she has a son at William E. R.
I was brought a car at winter of 1910-11 in Assembly from the Buick Co., or was it my own? The community was small. I got a mule that on my own. I had to work it out of a piece of land. In the fall of 1911 we left off the farm when I was working for an American farmer.

I went by car to the summer of 1912 in the city of Bingham without a license but in the spring of '13 I went to get a license and I was obliged to pay $100 for 1912 before I could get 1913. (I think this is a record that the city had not been able to have about) That was the summer of the cyclone. I walked with the rescue work down at 9th & Pine Street that night we tried twice blocks from the Cyclone area, we lived 1876 Pine street.

We had 16 people in our house after the Cyclone and for a month after and our shelter was torn. On July 12 days after the storm to you see we went through it sufficiently my wife died seven days at home, could not afford to go to the hospital Dr. Smith was our doctor he was your only man was killed in action and I had a cousin that was in the army hospital at the time she was a nurse. But the army must have had a hero in Australia and for Florida came to the west in 1912 but he's dead now. But the hero a hero at William E.

I worked in the Roundhouse in Canada, but it was Rat Portage then in the year 1898. I was turners helper. I used to shut all incoming engines for coal then drive them over the ash pit, and men would crawl underneath them and poke out the ashes. When they had the fires all clear, then the turner would put them on the turn table and put them (the engines) in the Roundhouse or send them out on another trip. They were just small engines in those days. Just had a few big ones.

Remember, we all worked on one engine for a week or more cleaning and polishing it and turning it up with flags and Bunting to be hooked onto a troop train of soldiers that was coming from B.C. The boys were on their way to South Africa. When the train pulled in and we had to take our engine out it was raining torrents so you know what would happen to the flags & Bunting. But we had done it anyway and were proud of it this must have been 1899 in the fall.
